awd_titl_txt: Linking Constitutional Content and Civil Society Relationships
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to understand how the contents of national constitutions change over time and how those changes affect civil society relationships in different countries. It focuses specifically on content related to strategies toward incorporation of minority groups into public and private domains and examines what consequences they might have on majority-minority relationships. The history of a national constitution represents changing understanding of the model of a nation. In many countries over time, it is the case that, with the rise of rights discourse, cultural rights of ethnic, linguistic, and religious minority groups often become constitutionally recognized, enabling citizens freedom to practice their culture to the extent such practice does not undermine the cultural unity of the nation. This research will propose to answer the following questions: How have these transformations changed over time? Who were the leading countries in these transformations, and what precipitated them to make those changes? Furthermore, have these changes in constitutional provisions about civil society relationships produced any changes in the actual practice of minority rights protection? 

This project tackles these questions by collecting data on all national constitutions in the world from 1789 to 2010 and coding them into three indexes of majority-minority relationships: the cultural homogeneity model, which emphasizes congruence of cultural and civic units; the individual cultural rights model, which allows minorities to practice individual cultural rights primarily in the private sphere; and multiculturalism, which promotes and protects minority groups' collective cultural rights. Using these indexes, and drawing on insights from sociology of law and globalization studies, the project will examine the causes and consequences of changes in constitutional stipulations of minority rights. The project will reveal the influence of global factors on seemingly national legal processes. The project will also use innovative methodologies -- multi-dimensional scaling and plagiarism detection software -- to examine more precisely how legal models diffuse globally and will present a model for future research on legal changes. As a detailed effort to collect comprehensive cross-national data on how constitutional minority rights provisions have changed over the last two hundred plus years, it will advance scholarly and public understanding of minority and ethnic relations, especially as they relate to globalization. The results of the research will be disseminated broadly and globally in presentations and publications that are accessible to policy makers and lay audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Tsutsui NSF Project Outcomes Report

In this project, we collected data on all national constitutions in the world from 1789 to 2010 and coded them into three indexes of majority-minority relationships: the cultural homogeneity model, which emphasizes congruence of cultural and political units; the individual cultural rights model, which allows minorities to practice individual cultural rights primarily in the private sphere; and multiculturalism, which promotes and protects minority groups’ collective cultural rights. In collaboration with Zach Elkins, Tom Ginsburg and their Comparative Constitution Project (CCP) team, we have coded over 800 constitutions to cover all the national constitutions that ever existed, using our 26-page codebook.

The data show that a one culture per nation model was dominant early on as an ideal for nation-states, but it gradually gave way to the individual rights model that allow minorities to practice their own culture and religion in private spheres, and then to the multicultural model that embraces minority culture and religion more openly in public spheres. One somewhat unexpected finding is that the multiculturalism/group rights model was more prevalent than we anticipated in the early 20th century, likely reflecting the inchoate cultural boundaries in that period.  

We also merged our newly created variables with other country level covariates such as GDP per capita, democracy level, and the level of participation in the international human rights regime to run some multivariate analyses that found support for many of our hypotheses: that more heterogeneous countries, more developed countries, newer constitutions, and more internationally connected countries are more likely to have constitutional provisions for minority rights protection. We also ran an analysis that traced the patterns of diffusion of certain types of constitutional provisions of minority rights, using plagiarism detection software to identify copying across different national constitutions and found a number of interesting patterns (e.g. high convergence in Central America).

In addition to these quantitative analyses, we organized a conference with experts of the relationships between national constitutions and actual practices on minority rights to deepen our understanding about those relationships. Using other funding sources, we assembled experts who were asked to provide paired comparisons on how majority-minority relationships shape constitutional provisions, and how the latter in turn shape the former via lower-level laws, court decisions, bureaucratic discretions, and interaction among private citizens. We have had comparisons of South Africa and Zimbabwe, Russia and Ukraine, Myanmar and Nepal, Indonesia and Senegal, and so on. This nuanced understanding of constitutions and minority rights further informed our data analysis to produce a comprehensive picture of the global evolution of minoirty rights norms.  

This project will inform policy makers and the broader public about how different modes of legal protection of minorities evolved over time and affected minority politics, and hence help them understand the impact of policy decisions on minority rights practices.

Modified by: Kiyoteru Tsutsui
